title: I inherited a house from my parents last year. There was a will and in the will my parents stated that I must give my son
question: a monetary gift. Since I've been living in the home and don't want to sell it, I refinanced the home and got the title changed into my name in order to take equity out in order to pay him. However, there are outstanding credit card debts as well that I can't afford to pay at this time. What are my options to take care of these credit cards and what will happen if I can't pay them?
answers:
Was probate opened? The credit card companies have one year from date of death to file a claim for payment in your parent's probate estate (meaning the last person who passed away). If a probate is not opened, meaning you were able to transfer the house into your name without probate, then the credit card company has to open probate themselves. You have no obligation to pay the debt until they open probate. If they do not open probate within one year, then the debts are forever barred from being collected.

If probate was opened, or if a creditor opens probate and files their claim for payment, then you would need to either pay the credit cards or negotiate.

By the way, credit card companies routinely negotiate this type of debt. They understand the high procedural hurdles they must pass through to get the money, so they are willing to bargain. I have seen some instances when they accept 20% of the amount owed.

Finally, you personally are not responsible for paying the credit card debts. They technically could file a lien on your house, but only IF they open probate, file a claim, the claim is rejected, and then they have to file a civil complaint to turn their debt into a judgement. This is not likely to happen.

Still it is worth while to sit down and consult an attorney on this one. A lot turns on how the house was transferred into your name.

The answer totally depends on a couple of things:

First, how were you able to transfer the house into your name? Were you and your parents joint tenants (i.e., your name was already on the property along with theirs), or did you inherit the house after undergoing probate (through the court)?

If you were a joint tenant, there is no need to undergo probate, and thus, the will would be a would only pertain to any personal property (which includes bank accounts). Assuming that there is no probate open, all that I can tell you for now is that you aren't personally liable for those credit cards. However, I do advise that they be paid somehow.

If there is a probate open, then you must ensure that the credit cards and your son must be paid before the probate can be closed.

It is unclear as to whether the will was put into a probate proceeding in court. You state you "inherited" the house. Was that as a result of a probate order or were you on titile as a surviving joint tenant? If there is/was a probate proceeding the creditors would have had to file claims in the probate and paid (or if there is not enough assets - paid prorata) before the probate could close and distribute the house to you. If there is not a probate, are there any other assets that require a probate proceeding to be transfered to the intended beneficiaries? If not, you have no liability to the creditors.

Sadly, I cannot speak to your direct issue, as the answer may differ from California to Texas. But your question raises two possibilities. Either the credit card debt is yours, in which case your creditors may seek collection from you for failure to pay. Or, the credit card debt belonged to your parents, and you're wondering if you are obligated to pay those debts before making the gift to your son. Again, while the answer may differ significantly in California, specific monetary gifts in a Texas Will are generally protected from being poached in order to satisfy debts of the decedent -- they are typically the last to be used for such things.

At the same time, it sounds like the cash that you have received from the equity loan would hardly be considered an asset of the Estate, and thus maybe not liable for any debt of the Estate. The house itself was the Estate asset, not the cash that you received after changing the title and taking out a new loan in your own name. If the Estate did not own any other assets, and assuming the credit card debt is your parents', their creditors may be left looking at no assets to recoup their debt with.
